Kettlebell alternating floor press                    | Isolation | Chest       | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Beginner     | 6   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on the floor with two kettlebells next to your shoulders.\n Position one in place on your chest and then the other, gripping the kettlebells on the handle with the palms facing forward.\n Extend both arms, so that the kettlebells are being held above your chest. Lower one kettlebell, bringing it to your chest and turn the wrist in the direction of the locked out kettlebell.\n Raise the kettlebell and repeat on the opposite side.\n
Hip Lift with Band                                    | Compound  | Glutes      | Bands         | Powerlifting          | Beginner     | 6   | Barbell Hip Thrust                            | Barbell glute bridge                                  | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | After choosing a suitable band, lay down in the middle of the rack, after securing the band on either side of you. If your rack doesn't have pegs, the band can be secured using heavy dumbbells or similar objects, just ensure they won't move.\n Adjust your position so that the band is directly over your hips. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the floor. Your hands can be on the floor or holding the band in position.\n Keeping your shoulders on the ground, drive through your heels to raise your hips, pushing into the band as high as you can.\n Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.\n
Forward Drag with Press                               | Isolation | Chest       | Other         | Strongman             | Beginner     | 6   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Attach a dual handled chain or rope attachment to the sled. You should be facing away from the sled, holding a handle in each hand.\n Begin the movement by moving forward for one step. Leaning forward, extend through the legs and hips to move, pausing with each step to extend through the elbows, pressing your hands forward. Step forward until you return to the start position prepared to press.\n
Medicine Ball Chest Pass                              | Compound  | Chest       | Medicine Ball | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 5.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | You will need a partner for this exercise. Lacking one, this movement can be performed against a wall.\n Begin facing your partner holding the medicine ball at your torso with both hands.\n Pull the ball to your chest, and reverse the motion by extending through the elbows. For sports applications, you can take a step as you throw.\n Your partner should catch the ball, and throw it back to you.\n Receive the throw with both hands at chest height.\n
Lying hamstring stretch with band                     | Isolation | Hamstrings  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back with one leg extended above you, with the hip at ninety degrees. Keep the other leg flat on the floor.\n Loop a belt, band, or rope over the ball of your foot. This will be your starting position.\n Pull on the belt to create tension in the calves and hamstrings. Hold this stretch for 10-30 seconds, and repeat with the other leg.\n
Cross-body shoulder stretch                           | Isolation | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Reach your left arm across your body and hold it straight. With your right hand, grasp your left elbow and pull it across your body towards your chest.\n
One Arm Against Wall                                  | Compound  | Lats        | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | From a standing position, place a bent arm against a wall or doorway.\n Slowly lean toward your arm until you feel a stretch in your lats.\n
Catch and Overhead Throw                              | Compound  | Lats        | Medicine Ball | Plyometrics           | Beginner     | 5.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin standing while facing a wall or a partner.\n Using both hands, position the ball behind your head, stretching as much as possible, and forcefully throw the ball forward.\n Ensure that you follow your throw through, being prepared to receive your rebound from your throw. If you are throwing against the wall, make sure that you stand close enough to the wall to receive the rebound, and aim a little higher than you would with a partner.\n
Smith Machine Hang Power Clean                        | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Unknown       | Strength              | Intermediate | 5.8 | Power clean                                   | Kettlebell Hang Clean                                 | Hang Clean                                          | Power Clean from Blocks                 | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Position the bar at knee height and load it to an appropriate weight.\n Take a pronated grip on the bar outside of shoulder width and unhook the bar from the machine. Your arms should be fully extended with your head and chest up. Your elbows should be pointed out with your shoulders back and down. Your hips should be back, loading the tension into the hamstrings. This will be your starting position.\n Initate the movement by forcefully extending the hips and knees, accelerating into the bar. Ensure that you keep your arms straight during this part of the motion.\n Upon full extension, rebend the hips and knees to lower your receiving position.\n Allow the arms to flex at this point, rotating the elbows around the bar to receive it on your shoulders.\n Extend through the hips and knees to come to a standing position with the bar racked on your shoulders to complete the movement.\n
Lying High Bench Barbell Curl                         | Isolation | Biceps      | Barbell       | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.8 | Cable rope preacher hammer curl               | Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline                | Face-down incline dumbbell biceps curl              | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie face forward on a tall flat bench while holding a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up). Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles. Your upper body should be positioned in a way that the upper chest is over the end of the bench and the barbell is hanging in front of you with the arms extended and perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.\n While keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary, curl the weight up in a semi-circular motion as you contract the biceps and exhale. Hold at the top of the movement for a second.\n As you inhale, slowly go back to the starting position. Tip: Maintain full control of the weight at all times and avoid any swinging. Remember, only the forearms should move throughout the movement.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
Squats - With Bands                                   | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Bands         | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.8 | Barbell front squat                           | Front Barbell Squat To A Bench                        | Front Squats With Two Kettlebells                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | To start out, make sure that the exercise band is at an even split between both the left and right side of the body. To do this, use your hands to grab both sides of the band and place both feet in the middle of the band. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.\n When holding the bands, they should be the same height on each side. You should be using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) and have the handles of the bands next to your face for this exercise. This is the starting position.\n Slowly start to bend the knees and lower the legs so that your thighs are parallel to the floor while exhaling.\n Use the heel of your feet to push your body up to the starting position as you exhale.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
Dynamic chest stretch                                 | Compound  | Chest       | Unknown       | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand with your hands together, arms extended directly in front of you. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping your arms straight, quickly move your arms back as far as possible and back in again, similar to an exaggerated clapping motion. Repeat 5-10 times, increasing speed as you do so.\n
Rhomboids SMR                                         | Isolation | Middle Back | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lay down with your back on the floor. Place a foam roll underneath your upper back, and cross your arms in front of you, protracting your shoulders. This will be your starting position.\n Raise your hips off of the ground, placing your weight onto the foam roll. Shift your weight to one side at a time, rolling over your middle and upper back. Pause at points of tension for 10-30 seconds.\n
Neck Bridge Prone                                     | Isolation | Neck        | Body Only     | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a prone position on the floor, on your hands and knees.\n Place your head next to your hands but a few inches nearer your legs, then extend your legs, driving your hips into the air.\n Transition into supporting your weight on your head by removing your hands from the ground. Perform this movement slowly, backing off if any serious discomfort is felt and avoiding it if you have any pre-existing neck injury.\n Hold the neck bridge for a period of time, and then carefully return your hands and knees to the floor.\n
Chain Press                                           | Compound  | Chest       | Other         | Powerlifting          | Beginner     | 5.6 | Dumbbell Bench Press                          | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin by connecting the chains to the cable handle attachments. Position yourself on the flat bench in the same position as for a dumbbell press. Your wrists should be pronated and arms perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.\n Lower the chains by flexing the elbows, unloading some of the chain onto the floor.\n Continue until your elbow forms a 90 degree angle, and then reverse the motion by extending through the elbow to lockout.\n
Standing Gastrocnemius Calf Stretch                   | Compound  | Calves      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.6 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place your right heel on a step with your knee extended and lean forward to grab your right toe with your right hand. Your left knee should be slightly bent and your back should be straight.\n Support your weight on your left leg and place your left hand on your left thigh.\n Pull your right toes toward your knee until you feel a stretch in your calf.\n
Skip                                                  | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 5.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start in a relaxed position with one leg slightly forward. This will be your starting position.\n Skip by executing a step-hop pattern of right-right-step to left-left-step, and so on, alternating back and forth.\n Perform fast skips by maintaining close contact with the ground and reduce air time, moving as quickly as possible.\n
Hamstring-SMR                                         | Isolation | Hamstrings  | Foam Roll     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | In a seated position, extend your legs over a foam roll so that it is position on the back of the upper legs. Place your hands to the side or behind you to help support your weight. This will be your starting position.\n Using your hands, lift your hips off of the floor and shift your weight on the foam roll to one leg. Relax the hamstrings of the leg you are stretching.\n Roll over the foam from below the hip to above the back of the knee, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat for the other leg.\n
Bench Press - With Bands                              | Compound  | Chest       | Bands         | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.5 | Dumbbell Bench Press                          | Lying cable chest fly                                 | Machine chest press                                 | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Using a flat bench secure a band under the leg of the bench that is nearest to your head.\n Once the band is secure, grab it by both handles and lie down on the bench.\n Extend your arms so that you are holding the band handles in front of you at shoulder width.\n Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.\n Bring down the handles slowly until your elbow forms a 90 degree angle. Keep full control at all times.\n As you breathe out, bring the handles up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\n Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.\n
Tricep Side Stretch                                   | Compound  | Triceps     | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Bring right arm across your body and over your left shoulder, holding your elbow with your left hand, until you feel a stretch in your tricep. Then repeat for your other arm.\n
Kneeling hip flexor stretch                           | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Kneel on a mat and bring your right knee up so the bottom of your foot is on the floor and extend your left leg out behind you so the top of your foot is on the floor.\n Shift your weight forward until you feel a stretch in your hip. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat for your other side.\n
Hug A Ball                                            | Compound  | Lower Back  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Seat yourself on the floor.\n Straddle an exercise ball between both legs and lower your hips down toward the floor.\n Hug your arms around the ball to support your body. Adjust your legs so that your feet are flat on the floor and your knees line up over your ankles. Keep a good grip on the ball so it doesn't roll away from you and send you back onto your buttocks.\n
Quadriceps SMR                                        | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Foam Roll     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lay facedown on the floor with your weight supported by your hands or forearms. Place a foam roll underneath one leg on the quadriceps, and keep the foot off of the ground. Make sure to relax the leg as much as possible. This will be your starting position.\n Shifting as much weight onto the leg to be stretched as is tolerable, roll over the foam from above the knee to below the hip, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Switch sides.\n
Upper Back-Leg Grab                                   | Isolation | Hamstrings  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | While seated, bend forward to hug your thighs from underneath with both arms.\n Keep your knees together and your legs extended out as you bring your chest down to your knees. You can also stretch your middle back by pulling your back away from your knees as your hugging them.\n
Dancer's Stretch                                      | Compound  | Lower Back  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit up on the floor.\n Cross your right leg over your left, keeping the knee bent. Your left leg is straight and down on the floor.\n Place your left arm on your right leg and your right hand on the floor.\n Rotate your upper body to the right, and hold for 10-20 seconds. Switch sides.\n
Elbow Circles                                         | Compound  | Shoulders   | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit or stand with your feet slightly apart.\n Place your hands on your shoulders with your elbows at shoulder level and pointing out.\n Slowly make a circle with your elbows. Breathe out as you start the circle and breathe in as you complete the circle.\n
Wall calf stretch                                     | Isolation | Calves      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand facing a wall from several feet away. Stagger your stance, placing one foot forward.\n Lean forward and rest your hands on the wall, keeping your heel, hip and head in a straight line.\n Attempt to keep your heel on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.\n
Spinal Stretch                                        | Isolation | Middle Back | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit in a chair so your back is straight and your feet planted on the floor.\n Interlace your fingers behind your head, elbows out and your chin down.\n Twist your upper body to one side about 3 times as far as you can. Then lean forward and twist your torso to reach your elbow to the floor on the inside of your knee.\n Return to upright position and then repeat for your other side.\n
Front Barbell Squat To A Bench                        | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Barbell       | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.3 | Barbell Squat To A Bench                      | Dumbbell Squat To A Bench                             | Barbell Full Squat                                  | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set a flat bench behind you and set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.\n Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\n Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).\n Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you touch the bench with your glutes. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\n Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead. If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more. The front squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly. This version of the squat is better suited for advanced athletes.\n
Anterior Tibialis-SMR                                 | Compound  | Calves      | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin seated on the ground with your legs bent and your feet on the floor.\n Using a Muscle Roller or a rolling pin, apply pressure to the muscles on the outside of your shins. Work from just below the knee to above the ankle, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.\n
Child's pose                                          | Isolation | Lower Back  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Get on your hands and knees, walk your hands in front of you.\n Lower your buttocks down to sit on your heels. Let your arms drag along the floor as you sit back to stretch your entire spine.\n Once you settle onto your heels, bring your hands next to your feet and relax. "breathe" into your back. Rest your forehead on the floor. Avoid this position if you have knee problems.\n
Kettlebell Dead Clean                                 | Isolation | Hamstrings  | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.\n Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.\n Lower the kettlebell, keeping the hamstrings loaded by keeping your back straight and your butt out.\n
Partner farmer's walk                                 | Compound  | Forearms    | Dumbbell      | Strength              | Beginner     | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place two dumbbells on the floor in front of you, making sure you have enough open space to walk. If you can’t reach the floor safely without rounding your back, elevate the weights off the floor. (When doing this as a competition, start side by side with your partner and make sure there’s enough room for both of you.)\n Squat down keeping your back flat—don’t bend over—and grasp the weights with a neutral grip. Stand back up by extending at the hips and knees; this will be your starting position.\n Keeping the weights at your sides, walk forward as far as you can; if necessary turn around and return the other way. Try to beat your partner for both distance and time.\n Descend into a squat to lower the weights back to the floor.\n
Seated Hamstring                                      | Compound  | Hamstrings  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | In a seated position with your legs extended, have your partner stand behind you. Now, lean forward as your partner braces your shoulders with their hands. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to push your torso back for 10-20 seconds, as your partner prevents any actual movement of your torso.\n Now relax your muscles as your partner increases the stretch by gently pushing your torso forward for 10-20 seconds.\n
Bar shoulder extension stretch                        | Isolation | Shoulders   | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand up straight with your legs together, holding a bodybar or broomstick.\n Hold the pole behind your hips with a wider than shoulder width grip. Your palms should be down and your thumbs facing out.\n Slowly lift your arms up behind your head. Don't force it if it gets hard to lift further.\n
Kneeling Forearm Stretch                              | Isolation | Forearms    | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start by kneeling on a mat with your palms flat and your fingers pointing back toward your knees.\n Slowly lean back keeping your palms flat on the floor until you feel a stretch in your wrists and forearms. Hold for 20-30 seconds.\n
Iron Crosses (stretch)                                | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie face down on the floor, with your arms extended out to your side, palms pressed to the floor. This will be your starting position.\n To begin, flex one knee and bring that leg across the back of your body, attempting to touch it to the ground near the opposite hand.\n Promptly return the leg to the starting postion, and quickly repeat with the other leg. Continue alternating for 10-20 repetitions.\n
Seated Floor Hamstring Stretch                        | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Unknown       | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit on a mat with your right leg extended in front of you and your left leg bent with your foot against your right inner thigh.\n Lean forward from your hips and reach for your ankle until you feel a stretch in your hamstring. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat for your other side.\n
Arm circle                                            | Compound  | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.1 | Back Flyes - With Bands                       | Cable Internal Rotation                               | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand up and extend your arms straight out by the sides. The arms should be parallel to the floor and perpendicular (90-degree angle) to your torso. This will be your starting position.\n Slowly start to make circles of about 1 foot in diameter with each outstretched arm. Breathe normally as you perform the movement.\n Continue the circular motion of the outstretched arms for about ten seconds. Then reverse the movement, going the opposite direction.\n\nTip: Ten second movements equal one set and each circle equals one repetition.\n
Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge                               | Isolation | Lower Back  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie down with your feet on the floor, heels directly under your knees.\n Lift only your tailbone to the ceiling to stretch your lower back. (Don't lift the entire spine yet.) Pull in your stomach.\n To go into a bridge, lift the entire spine except the neck.\n
Seated Biceps                                         | Compound  | Biceps      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit on the floor with your knees bent and your partner standing behind you. Extend your arms straight behind you with your palms facing each other. Your partner will hold your wrists for you. This will be the starting position.\n Attempt to flex your elbows, while your partner prevents any actual movement.\n After 10-20 seconds, relax your arms while your partner gently pulls your wrists up to stretch your biceps. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is appropriate to prevent injury or overstretching.\n
90/90 Hamstring                                       | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back, with one leg extended straight out.\n With the other leg, bend the hip and knee to 90 degrees. You may brace your leg with your hands if necessary. This will be your starting position.\n Extend your leg straight into the air, pausing briefly at the top. Return the leg to the starting position.\n Repeat for 10-20 repetitions, and then switch to the other leg.\n
All Fours Quad Stretch                                | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 5   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off on your hands and knees, then lift your leg off the floor and hold the foot with your hand.\n Use your hand to hold the foot or ankle, keeping the knee fully flexed, stretching the quadriceps and hip flexors.\n Focus on extending your hips, thrusting them towards the floor. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.\n
Cable Judo Flip                                       | Compound  | Abdominals  | Cable         | Strength              | Beginner     | 5   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Connect a rope attachment to a tower, and move the cable to the lowest pulley position. Stand with your side to the cable with a wide stance, and grab the rope with both hands.\n Twist your body away from the pulley as you bring the rope over your shoulder like you’re performing a judo flip.\n Shift your weight between your feet as you twist and crunch forward, pulling the cable downward.\n Return to the starting position and repeat until failure.\n Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.\n\nTip: Although this should be one continuous movement, think of it as two separate ab movements: the twist for obliques and the crunch for abs. This will help with the mind-muscle connection. Also, over exaggerate the end of the crunch by pausing for a moment and clinching your abs in an isometric hold before releasing.
Exercise ball torso rotation                          | Isolation | Abdominals  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 5   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand upright holding an exercise ball with both hands. Extend your arms so the ball is straight out in front of you. This will be your starting position.\n Rotate your torso to one side, keeping your eyes on the ball as you move. Now, rotate back to the opposite direction. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.\n
Lying quad stretch with band                          | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lay on your side. Loop a belt, rope, or band around your top foot. Flex the knee and extend your hip, attempting to touch your glutes with your foot, and holding the belt with your hands. This will be your starting position.\n With the belt being held over the shoulder or overhead, gently pull to increase the stretch in the quadriceps. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.\n
Cat Stretch                                           | Compound  | Lower Back  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Position yourself on the floor on your hands and knees.\n Pull your belly in and round your spine, lower back, shoulders, and neck, letting your head drop.\n Hold for 15 seconds.\n
Calf Stretch Elbows Against Wall                      | Isolation | Calves      | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand facing a wall from a couple feet away.\n Lean against the wall, placing your weight on your forearms.\n Attempt to keep your heels on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds. You may move further or closer the wall, making it more or less difficult, respectively.\n
Behind Head Chest Stretch                             | Compound  | Chest       | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit on the floor with your legs comfortably in front of you. Your chest should be up and your back straight. Put your hands on the back of your head and interlace your fingers. This will be your starting position\n Have your partner stand behind you and put his/her hands on the inside of your elbows. Allow them to pull back on your elbows until you feel a stretch in your chest and front delts. Hold for 10 seconds.\n After 10 seconds, try to bring your elbows in against your partner's resistance. Hold that contraction for 6 seconds.\n Now, relax your muscles and have your partner gently pull the elbows back as far as it comfortable for you for 30 seconds. (If you want, try contracting your upper back for greater ROM gains.)\n
Alternating Hang Clean                                | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Beginner     | 4.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.\n Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell in a hanging position. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so.\n Lower the cleaned kettlebell to a hanging position and clean the alternate kettlebell. Repeat.\n
Calf Raises - With Bands                              | Compound  | Calves      | Bands         | Strength              | Beginner     | 4.8 | Calf Press On The Leg Press Machine           | Standing barbell calf raise                           | Standing Dumbbell Calf Raise                        | n/a                                     | Not Yet Rated                 | Calf Raise On A Dumbbell | -                        | -                   | -                     | Grab an exercise band and stand on it with your toes making sure that the length of the band between the foot and the arms is the same for both sides.\n While holding the handles of the band, raise the arms to the side of your head as if you were getting ready to perform a shoulder press. The palms should be facing forward with the elbows bent and to the sides. This movement will create tension on the band. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping the hands by your shoulder, stand up on your toes as you exhale and contract the calves hard at the top of the movement.\n After a one second contraction, slowly go back down to the starting position.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
Calf Raise On A Dumbbell                              | Isolation | Calves      | Dumbbell      | Strength              | Beginner     | 4.8 | Standing Calf Raises                          | Calf Press On The Leg Press Machine                   | Standing Dumbbell Calf Raise                        | n/a                                     | Not Yet Rated                 | Calf Raises - With Bands | -                        | -                   | -                     | Hang on to a sturdy object for balance and stand on a dumbbell handle, preferably one with round plates so that it rolls as in this manner you have to work harder to stabilize yourself; thus increasing the effectiveness of the exercise.\n Now roll your foot slightly forward so that you can get a nice stretch of the calf. This will be your starting position.\n Lift the calf as you roll your foot over the top of the handle so that you get a full extension. Exhale during the execution of this movement. Contract the calf hard at the top and hold for a second. Tip: As you come up, roll the dumbbell slightly backward.\n Now inhale as you roll the dumbbell slightly forward as you come down to get a better stretch.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
Lying glute stretch                                   | Compound  | Glutes      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | From a lying position, bend your knees and keep your feet on the floor.\n Place your ankle of one foot on your opposite knee.\n Grasp the thigh or knee of the bottom leg and pull both of your legs into the chest. Relax your neck and shoulders. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.\n

Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.\n
Side Neck Stretch                                     | Isolation | Neck        | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start with your shoulders relaxed, gently tilt your head towards your shoulder.\n Assist stretch with a gentle pull on the side of the head.\n
Elbows Back                                           | Compound  | Chest       | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand up straight.\n Place both hands on your lower back, fingers pointing downward and elbows out.\n Then gently pull your elbows back aiming to touch them together.\n
Dynamic Back Stretch                                  | Isolation | Lats        | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping your arms straight, swing them straight up in front of you 5-10 times, increasing the range of motion each time until your arms are above your head.\n
Seated bar twist                                      | Compound  | Abdominals  | Barbell       | Strength              | Intermediate | 4.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start out by sitting at the end of a flat bench with a barbell placed on top of your thighs. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.\n Grip the bar with your palms facing down and make sure your hands are wider than shoulder width apart from each other. Begin to lift the barbell up over your head until your arms are fully extended.\n Now lower the barbell behind your head until it is resting along the base of your neck. This is the starting position.\n While keeping your feet and head stationary, move your waist from side to side so that your oblique muscles feel the contraction. Only move from side to side as far as your waist will allow you to go. Stretching or moving too far can cause an injury to occur. Tip: Use a slow and controlled motion.\n Remember to breathe out while twisting your body to the side and in when moving back to the starting position.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
One Half Locust                                       | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie facedown on the floor.\n Put your left hand under your left hipbone to pad your hip and pubic bone.\n Bend your right knee so you can hold the foot in your right hand.\n Lift the foot in the air and simultaneously lift your shoulders off the floor. This also stretches the right hip flexor and the chest and shoulders. Switch sides. If it doesn't bother your back, you can try it with both arms and legs at the same time.\n
Latissimus dorsi SMR                                  | Compound  | Lats        | Foam Roll     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | While lying on the floor, place a foam roll under your back and to one side, just behind your arm pit. This will be your starting position.\n Keep the arm of the side being stretched behind and to the side of you as you shift your weight onto your lats, keeping your upper body off of the ground. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and switch sides.\n
Seated Overhead Stretch                               | Isolation | Abdominals  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit up straight on an exercise mat.\n Touch the soles of your feet together with your feet six to eight inches in front of your hips.\n Place one hand on the floor beside you and your other hand behind your head.\n Lift your elbow to the ceiling as you incline your torso to the other side. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.\n
Seated Front Deltoid                                  | Isolation | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit upright on the floor with your legs bent, your partner standing behind you. Stick your arms straight out to your sides, with your palms facing the ground. Attempt to move them as far behind you as possible, as your assistant holds your wrists. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping your elbows straight, attempt to move your arms to the front, with your partner gently restraining you to prevent any actual movement for 10-20 seconds.\n Now, relax your muscles and allow your partner to gently increase the stretch on the shoulders and chest. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.\n
Lower back SMR                                        | Compound  | Lower Back  | Foam Roll     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | In a seated position, place a foam roll under your lower back. Cross your arms in front of you and protract your shoulders. This will be your starting position.\n Raise your hips off of the floor and lean back, keeping your weight on your lower back. Now shift your weight slightly to one side, keeping your weight off of the spine and on the muscles to the side of it. Roll over your lower back, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.\n
Hug Knees To Chest                                    | Isolation | Lower Back  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie down on your back and pull both knees up to your chest.\n Hold your arms under the knees, not over (that would put to much pressure on your knee joints).\n Slowly pull the knees toward your shoulders. This also stretches your buttocks muscles.\n
World's greatest stretch                              | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | This is a three-part stretch. Begin by lunging forward, with your front foot flat on the ground and on the toes of your back foot. With your knees bent, squat down until your knee is almost touching the ground. Keep your torso erect, and hold this position for 10-20 seconds.\n Now, place the arm on the same side as your front leg on the ground, with the elbow next to the foot. Your other hand should be placed on the ground, parallel to your lead leg, to help support you during this portion of the stretch.\n After 10-20 seconds, place your hands on either side of your front foot. Raise the toes of the front foot off of the ground, and straighten your leg. You may need to reposition your rear leg to do so. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then repeat the entire sequence for the other side.\n
Standing Hip Flexors                                  | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand up straight with the spine vertical, the left foot slightly in front of the right.\n Bend both knees and lift the back heel off the floor as you press the right hip forward. You can't get a thorough, deep stretch in this position, however, because it's hard to relax the hip flexor and stand on it at the same time. Switch sides.\n

Start by extending your legs in front of you in a V.\n With your hands on the floor, lean forward as far as possible. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.\n
Looking At Ceiling                                    | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Kneel on the floor, holding your heels with both hands.\n Lift your buttocks up and forward while bringing your head back to look up at the ceiling, to give an arch in your back.\n

Switch sides.\n
Upper Back Stretch                                    | Compound  | Middle Back | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Clasp fingers together with your thumbs pointing down, round your shoulders as you reach your hands forward.\n
Alternating lunge jump                                | Compound  | Hamstrings  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Being in a standing position. Jump into a split leg position, with one leg forward and one leg back, flexing the knees and lowering your hips slightly as you do so.\n As you descend, immediately reverse direction, standing back up and jumping, reversing the position of your legs. Repeat 5-10 times on each leg.\n
Chair Upper Body Stretch                              | Compound  | Shoulders   | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit on the edge of a chair, gripping the back of it.\n Straighten your arms, keeping your back straight, and pull your upper body forward so you feel a stretch. Hold for 20-30 seconds.\n
Seated Calf Stretch                                   | Isolation | Calves      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit up straight on an exercise mat.\n Bend one knee and put that foot on the floor to stabilize the torso.\n Straighten your other leg and flex your ankle.\n Using a band, towel, or your hand if you can reach, pull the toes toward you. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.\n
Shoulder Raise                                        | Compound  | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 4.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Relax your arms to your sides and raise your shoulders up toward your ears, then back down.\n
Downward Facing Balance                               | Compound  | Glutes      | Exercise Ball | Strength              | Beginner     | 4   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie facedown on top of an exercise ball.\n While resting on your stomach on the ball, walk your hands forward along the floor and lift your legs, extending your elbows and knees.\n
Kneeling Arm Drill                                    | Compound  | Shoulders   | None          | Plyometrics           | Beginner     | 4   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | This drill helps increase arm efficiency during the run. Begin kneeling, left foot in front, right knee down. Apply pressure through the front heel to keep your glutes and hamstrings activated.\n Begin by blocking the arms in long, pendulum like swings. Close the arm angle, blocking with the arms as you would when jogging, progressing to a run and finally a sprint.\n As soon as your hands pass the hip, accelerate them forward during the sprinting motion to move them as quickly as possible.\n Switch knees and repeat.\n
Adductor SMR                                          | Compound  | Adductors   | Foam Roll     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 4   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie face down with one leg on a foam roll.\n Rotate the leg so that the foam roll contacts against your inner thigh. Shift as much weight onto the foam roll as can be tolerated.\n While trying to relax the muscles if the inner thigh, roll over the foam between your hip and knee, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat with the other leg.\n
Crossover Reverse Lunge                               | Compound  | Lower Back  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.\n Perform a rear lunge by stepping back with one foot and flexing the hips and front knee. As you do so, rotate your torso across the front leg.\n After a brief pause, return to the starting position and repeat on the other side, continuing in an alternating fashion.\n
Overhead Stretch                                      | Compound  | Abdominals  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Standing straight up, lace your fingers together and open your palms to the ceiling. Keep your shoulders down as you extend your arms up.\n To create a full torso stretch, pull your tailbone down and stabilize your torso as you do this. Stretch the muscles on both the front and the back of the torso.\n
Frog Hops                                             | Compound  | Quadriceps  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.9 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand with your hands behind your head, and squat down keeping your torso upright and your head up. This will be your starting position.\n Jump forward several feet, avoiding jumping unnecessarily high. As your feet contact the ground, absorb the impact through your legs, and jump again. Repeat this action 5-10 times.\n
Side Lying Groin Stretch                              | Compound  | Adductors   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off by lying on your right side and bend your right knee in front of you to stabilize the torso.\n Rest your head on your right hand or shoulder. Lift your left leg upward and hold it by the back of the knee (easier) or the foot (harder).\n Pull your left knee in toward your left shoulder and simultaneously press your foot or knee down to the floor. To intensify this stretch, straighten your left leg. Switch sides.\n
Chin To Chest Stretch                                 | Compound  | Neck        | Unknown       | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Get into a seated position on the floor.\n Place both hands at the rear of your head, fingers interlocked, thumbs pointing down and elbows pointing straight ahead. Slowly pull your head down to your chest. Hold for 20-30 seconds.\n
Middle Back Stretch                                   | Isolation | Middle Back | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand so your feet are shoulder width apart and your hands are on your hips.\n Twist at your waist until you feel a stretch. Hold for 10 to 15 seconds, then twist to the other side.\n
Runner's Stretch                                      | Isolation | Hamstrings  | None          | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.6 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | It's easiest to get into this stretch if you start standing up, put one leg behind you, and slowly lower your torso down to the floor.\n Keep the front heel on the floor (if it lifts up, scoot your other leg further back).\n Place your hands on either side of your front leg. To get more out of this stretch, push your butt up toward the ceiling, and then gradually lower it back toward the floor. You'll Stretch the hip flexor of the back leg and the hamstring and buttocks of the front.\n
One Handed Hang                                       | Isolation | Lats        | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.6 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Grab onto a chinup bar with one hand, using a pronated grip. Keep your feet on the floor or a step. Allow the majority of your weight to hang from that hand, while keeping your feet on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds and switch sides.\n
Exercise ball chest stretch                           | Isolation | Chest       | Exercise Ball | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.6 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Get on your hands and knees next to an exercise ball.\n Place your elbows on top of the ball, keeping your arm out to your side. This will be your starting position.\n Lower your torso towards the floor, keeping your elbow on top of the ball. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, and repeat with the other arm.\n
Adductor/Groin                                        | Isolation | Adductors   | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.6 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back with your feet raised towards the ceiling.\n Have your partner hold your feet or ankles. Abduct your legs as far as you can. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to squeeze your legs together for 10 or more seconds, while your partner prevents you from doing so.\n Now, relax the muscles in your legs as your partner pushes your feet apart, stretching as far as is comfortable for you. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is adequate to prevent overstretching or injury.\n
Knee Across The Body                                  | Isolation | Glutes      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie down on the floor with your right leg straight. Bend your left leg and lower it across your body, holding the knee down toward the floor with your right hand. (The knee doesn't need to touch the floor if you're tight.)\n Place your left arm comfortably beside you and turn your head to the left. Imagine you have a weight tied to your tailbone. let your tailbone fall back toward the floor as your chest reaches in the opposite direction to stretch your lower back. Switch sides.\n
Rear Leg Raises                                       | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place yourself on your hands knees on an exercise mat. Your head should be looking forward and the bend of the knees should create a 90-degree angle between the hamstrings and the calves. This will be your starting position.\n Extend one leg up and behind you. The knee and hip should both extend. Repeat for 5-10 repetitions, and then switch sides.\n
Medicine ball scoop throw                             | Compound  | Shoulders   | Medicine Ball | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 3.4 | Power snatch-                                 | Tire flip                                             | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Assume a semisquat stance with a medicine ball in your hands. Your arms should hang so the ball is near your feet.\n Begin by thrusting the hips forward as you extend through the legs, jumping up.\n As you do, swing your arms up and over your head, keeping them extended, releasing the ball at the peak of your movement. The goal is to throw the ball the greatest distance behind you.\n
Overhead Triceps                                      | Compound  | Triceps     | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your elbow and wrist. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to extend the arm straight into the air as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.\n After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the tricep by applying gentle pressure to the wrist. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.\n
Peroneals Stretch                                     | Compound  | Calves      | Bands         | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot.
