This will be your starting position.\n With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is inverted, with the inside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.\n
On Your Side Quad Stretch                             | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off by lying on your right side, with your right knee bent at a 90-degree angle resting on the floor in front of you (this stabilizes the torso).\n Bend your left knee behind you and hold your left foot with your left hand. To stretch your hip flexor, press your left hip forward as you push your left foot back into your hand. Switch sides.\n
On-Your-Back Quad Stretch                             | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.3 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on a flat bench or step, and hang one leg and arm over the side.\n Bend the knee and hold the top of the foot. As you do this, be careful not to arch your lower back.\n Pull the belly button to the spine to stay in neutral. Press your foot down and into your hand. To add the hip stretch, lift the hip of the leg you're holding up toward the ceiling.\n Switch sides.\n
Chair Lower Back Stretch                              | Compound  | Lats        | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit upright on a chair.\n Bend to one side with your arm over your head. You can hold onto the chair with your free hand.\n Hold for 10 seconds, and repeat for your other side.\n
Standing side bend stretch                            | Compound  | Lats        | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 3.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Take a slightly wider than hip distance stance with your knees slightly bent.\n Place your right hand on your right hip to support the spine.\n Raise your left arm in a vertical line and place your left hand behind your head. Keep it there as you incline your torso to the right.\n Keep your weight evenly distributed between both legs (don't lean into your left hip). Switch sides.\n
Brachialis SMR                                        | Isolation | Biceps      | Foam Roll     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.2 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your side, with your upper arm against the foam roller. The upper arm should be more or less aligned with your body, with the outside of the bicep pressed against the foam roller.\n Raise your hips off of the floor, supporting your weight on your arm and on your feet. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and then switch sides.\n
Seated Glute                                          | Compound  | Glutes      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | In a seated position with your knees bent, cross one ankle over the opposite knee. Your partner will stand behind you. Now, lean forward as your partner braces your shoulders with their hands. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to push your torso back for 10-20 seconds, as your partner prevents any actual movement of your torso.\n Now relax your muscles as your partner increases the stretch by gently pushing your torso forward for 10-20 seconds.\n
Standing Pelvic Tilt                                  | Isolation | Lower Back  | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3.1 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off with your feet hip-distance apart.\n Bend your knees slightly to keep them soft and springy.\n You may want to move your pelvis forward and backward and back few times before holding the tailbone forward in this stretch.\n
Double-kettlebell windmill                            | Compound  | Shoulders   | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Intermediate | 3   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place a kettlebell in front of your front foot and clean and press a kettlebell overhead with your opposite arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward.\n Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the locked out kettlebell.\n Bending at the hip to one side, sticking your butt out, slowly lean until you can retrieve the kettlebell from the floor. Keep your eyes on the kettlebell that you hold over your head at all times.\n Pause for a second after retrieving the kettlebell from the ground and reverse the motion back to the starting position.\n
Lying Glute                                           | Compound  | Glutes      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back with your partner kneeling beside you.\n Flex the hip of one leg, raising it off of the floor. Rotate the leg so the foot is over the opposite hip, the lower leg perpendicular to your body. Your partner should hold the knee and ankle in place. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to push your leg towards your partner, who should be preventing any actual movement of the leg.\n After 10-20 seconds, completely relax as your partner gently pushes the ankle and knee towards your chest. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching.\n
Pass-through stretch with band                        | Compound  | Chest       | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 3   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off by standing with your legs together, holding a bodybar or a broomstick.\n Take a slightly wider than shoulder width grip on the pole and hold it in front of you with your palms facing down.\n Carefully lift the pole up and behind your head.\n\nRemain aware of your lower body alignment. Keep your stomach muscles tucked in and your lower back muscles contracted to avoid arching your lower back.
Lying Bent Leg Groin                                  | Compound  | Adductors   | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 2.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back with your knees bent and the soles of the feet pressed together. Have your partner hold your knees. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to squeeze your knees together, while your partner prevents any movement from occurring.\n After 10-20 seconds, relax your muscles as your partner gently pushes your knees towards the floor. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching.\n
Neck-SMR                                              | Isolation | Neck        | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 2.8 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Using a muscle roller or a rolling pin, place the roller behind your head and against your neck. Make sure that you do not place the roller directly against the spine, but turned slightly so that the roller is pressed against the muscles to either side of the spine. This will be your starting position.\n Starting at the top of your neck, slowly roll down the muscles of your neck, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds.\n
Foot-SMR                                              | Isolation | Calves      | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 2.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | This exercise stretches the fascia of the muscles in the feet. Start off seated with your shoes removed. Using a foot roller or a similar object, such as a small section of pvc pipe, place your foot against the roller across the arch of your foot. This will be your starting position.\n Press down firmly, rolling across the arch of your foot. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and then switch feet.\n
One Knee To Chest                                     | Isolation | Glutes      | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 2.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off by lying on the floor.\n Extend one leg straight and pull the other knee to your chest. Hold under the knee joint to protect the kneecap.\n Gently tug that knee toward your nose.\n Switch sides. This stretches the buttocks and lower back of the bent leg and the hip flexor of the straight leg.\n
Standing Elevated Quad Stretch                        | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 2.7 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start by standing with your back about two to three feet away from a bench or step.\n Lift one leg behind you and rest your foot on the step,either on your instep or the ball of your foot, whichever you find most comfortable.\n Keep your supporting knee slightly bent and avoid letting that knee extend out beyond your toes. Switch sides.\n
Wrist Circles                                         | Isolation | Forearms    | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 2.5 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start by standing straight with your feet being shoulder width apart from each other. Elevate your arms to the side of you until they are fully extended and parallel to the floor at a height that is evenly aligned with your shoulders. Tip: Your torso and arms should form the letter "T: Your palms should be facing down. This is the starting position.\n Keeping your entire body stationary except for the wrists, begin to rotate both wrists forward in a circular motion. Tip: Pretend that you are trying to draw circles by using your hands as the brush. Breathe normally as you perform this exercise.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n\nVariation: You can hold small weights to add resistance.
Chair Leg Extended Stretch                            | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 2.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit upright in a chair and grip the seat on the sides.\n Raise one leg, extending the knee, flexing the ankle as you do so.\n Slowly move that leg outward as far as you can, and then back to the center and down.\n Repeat for your other leg.\n
IT Band and Glute Stretch                             | Compound  | Abductors   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 2.4 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Loop a belt, rope, or band around one of your feet, and swing that leg across your body to the opposite side, keeping the leg extended as you lay on the ground. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping your foot off of the floor, pull on the belt, using the tension to pull the toes up. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other side.\n
Single-leg lying cross-over stretch                   | Compound  | Abductors   | Body Only     | Stretching            | Beginner     | 1.6 | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back with your legs extended.\n Cross one leg over your body with the knee bent, attempting to touch the knee to the ground. Your partner should kneel beside you, holding your shoulder down with one hand and controlling the crossed leg with the other. this will be your starting position.\n Attempt to raise the bent knee off of the ground as your partner prevents any actual movement.\n After 10-20 seconds, relax the leg as your partner gently presses the knee towards the floor. Repeat with the other side.\n
Side-Lying Floor Stretch                              | Compound  | Lats        | None          | Stretching            | Beginner     | 1   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | First lie on your left side, bending your left knee in front of you to stabilize your torso (use your abdominal muscles as well to hold you upright).\n Straighten your right leg and rest the right foot on the floor behind your left. Straighten your right arm over your head and gently pull on your right wrist to stretch the entire right side of the body. Switch sides.\n
Posterior Tibialis Stretch                            | Compound  | Calves      | Bands         | Stretching            | Intermediate | 1   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.\n With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is everted, with the outside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.\n
Overhead Lat                                          | Isolation | Lats        | Other         | Stretching            | Beginner     | 1   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your tricep and wrist. This will be your starting position.\n Attempt to pull your upper arm to your side as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.\n After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the lat by applying gentle pressure to the tricep. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.\n
Pyramid                                               | Compound  | Lower Back  | Body Only     | Stretching            | Intermediate | 1   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start off by rolling your torso forward onto the ball so your hips rest on top of the ball and become the highest point of your body.\n Rest your hands and feet on the floor. Your arms and legs can be slightly bent or straight, depending on the size of the ball, your flexibility, and the length of your limbs. This also helps develop stabilizing strength in your torso and shoulders.\n
Sled Drag - Harness                                   | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Other         | Strongman             | Intermediate | 0   | Sled Push                                     | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | To begin, load the sled with the desired weight and attach the pulling strap. You can pull with handles, use a harness, or attach the pulling strap to a weight belt. Typically, sled drags are performed for a distance as fast as possible, from 30-100 feet. The sled can be pulled backwards to emphasize the quadriceps, or forwards to emphasize the posterior chain.2. Whether pulling forwards or backwards, lean in the direction of travel and progress by extending through the hips and knees.\n
Burpee over barbell                                   | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Other         | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place a loaded barbell on the floor and stand parallel to the bar with your legs shoulder-width apart. This will be your starting position.\n Place your hands on the floor and kick your legs back so you end up with your stomach and thighs on the floor. Your elbows should be bent. This should be done quickly.\n From this position, press up like you're doing a push-up and push your hips up. Jump your feet under your hips and begin to stand as you prepare to jump up.\n As you jump, jump laterally (to the left or right) so that you land on the other side of the bar. This is one repetition.\n Repeat steps 2 to 4 and return to the other side of the bar. Repeat for recommended number of repetitions.\n
Medicine ball rotational throw                        | Compound  | Abdominals  | Medicine Ball | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Russian twist                                 | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand with your side several feet away from a wall. Hold a medicine ball with both hands in an athletic stance. This will be your starting position.\n Begin by rotating your shoulders away from the wall winding up in preparation for the throw. Immediately reverse direction, turning your shoulders and releasing the ball against the wall as fast as you can.\n Receive the ball on the bounce and repeat the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.\n
Medicine ball sprawl to chest press                   | Compound  | Chest       | Medicine Ball | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start with a medicine ball a couple feet in front of you. With your feet about hip-width apart, squat down and place your hands on the medicine ball while simultaneously jumping your feet out into a plank position. Quickly jump your feet out into a wide squat stance, pick up the ball, and press it forward, away from your chest.\n Reverse the motion by bringing the ball back into your chest, squatting down, and jumping back into a plank position. This is one rep. Repeat for the recommended number of reps.\n For the duration of this exercise the medicine ball should never leave your hands.\n
Bosu Ball Crunch                                      | Isolation | Abdominals  | Unknown       | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Crunches                                      | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lay with the small of your back against the round side of a Bosu ball. Your knees should be bent with your feet flat on the ground. Fold your arms across your chest. This will be your starting position.\n Perform the movement by flexing the lumbar spine raising your torso. Do not flex the hips.\n At the top of the motion pause, and then return to the starting position.\n
Dumbbell Overhead Squat                               | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Unknown       | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | From a standing position, press a pair of dumbbells overhead by extending the elbows and flexing the shoulders. You should be looking directly forward, with your chest up, knees and hips slightly bent, and your back straight. This will be your starting position.\n Descend into a squat by flexing your hips and knees. As you squat, keep your weight on your heels and push your knees out. Maintain proper curvature of your entire spine, from the lower back all the way up through your cervical spine.\n Descend as far as your flexibility allows or until you have reached a full squat position. Avoid excessive forward lean, rounding your lumbar or thoracic spine, and keep the dumbbell in place throughout the exercise.\n After a brief pause, return to the starting position by extending through the hips and knees. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions\n
Front Squat Push Press                                | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Barbell       | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Set the bar in a rack slightly below shoulder level so that when under it, your knees are slightly bent. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids, pushing into the clavicles, and lightly touching the throat. Your hands should be in a clean grip, touching the bar only with your fingers to help keep it in position.\n Push upward into the bar and push your hips forward to unrack. Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder-width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head and elbows up at all times. Your triceps should remain parallel with the ground. Keep a neutral neck and flat back. This will be your starting position.\n Descend into a squat by pushing your hips and butt back. Continue down until the upper legs are at or just below parallel to the floor. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.\n As you prepare to ascend, push through your heels and begin to wrap your fingers tightly around the bar for a firm grip.\n Begin pressing the bar up towards the ceiling as you begin squatting upwards, allowing your neck to hyperextend so that the bar has room to move. A final position will be one in which your arms are fully extended overhead and knees slightly bent, maintaining tight ness from head to toe.\n Lower the bar slowly to the starting position, allowing your knees to bend slightly to lessen the blow. Repeat for recommended number of repetitions.\n
Single-arm half-kneeling shoulder press               | Compound  | Shoulders   | Dumbbell      | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Alternating Cable Shoulder Press              | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Select an appropriate load and adopt a half-kneeling position on the floor. Your right knee should be down, and your left knee up; take the weight with your right hand. Clean the dumbbell to your shoulder, using both hands if necessary. You should start with a neutral grip, with the palm in. Keep your head up, shoulders back, and your spine neutral. This will be your starting position.\n Initiate the movement by extending the arm, flexing and abducting the shoulder to rotate the arm as you press above your head. Pause at the top of the motion before reversing the movement to return to the starting position.\n Complete the desired number of repetitions before switching to the opposite side.\n
Hand Stand Push-Up                                    | Compound  | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Standing dumbbell shoulder press              | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin by facing a wall, standing 3 to 4 feet away from it. Bending at the waist, lower your arms down to the ground and place them 4 to 6 inches from the wall, while simultaneously kicking your legs up towards the wall—this is to be done in a quick, continuous motion.\n Keep your glutes and abdominals tight, and your arms and legs fully extended. This will be your starting position. Begin to lower yourself to the ground, maintaining fully extended legs and feet together. Keep your elbows at roughly a 45 degree angle—not flared completely out nor in a straight line with your upper arms.\n Lower yourself until the top of your head grazes the ground. Once the bottom position is achieved, push through the hands, keeping your legs straight, and glutes and core tight, and return to the starting position. Repeat for the recommended number of repetitions.\n
Weighted Push-Up                                      | Compound  | Chest       | Other         | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start by holding a plate with both hands at chest level. Lower yourself down into a kneeling position, and bring the plate behind your head. Take one hand off of the plate and bring it down to the floor to help support your body while you place the weight on your back. Extend your legs back so that you are in a full plank position. Once the plate feels secure on your back, bring your other arm down and place your hands about 36 inches apart. This part can be simplified by having a partner place the weight on your back. This will be your starting position.\n Lower yourself down until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale. Next, breathe out and press your upper body back into the starting position.\n Repeat this pattern for the desired number of repetitions.\n
Wall walk                                             | Compound  | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a push-up position with your feet against the wall.\n Walk your feet up the wall while simultaneously walking your hands back towards the wall. Keep your core as tight as possible. Walk up until you are as flat to the wall as you can get.\n Walk your hands away from the wall and your feet down the wall until you are back in the push-up position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.\n
Dumbbell walking lunge-                               | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Other         | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Barbell walking lunge                         | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Select a plate that you’re able to hold overhead for a time of at least 30 seconds. Grasping the plate with both hands, raise it overhead until your arms are fully extended. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, arms fully extended overhead. This will be your starting position.\n Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.\n Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up. Step forward with your rear foot, repeating the lunge on the opposite leg.\n Repeat for recommended number of repetitions.\n
Suitcase crunch                                       | Isolation | Abdominals  | Other         | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | V-up                                          | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin by lying on your back on the ground. Your legs should be straight and your arms extended behind your head. This will be your starting position.\n To perform the movement, tuck the knees toward your chest, rotating your pelvis to lift your glutes from the floor. As you do so, flex the spine, bringing your arms back over your head to perform a simultaneous crunch motion.\n After a brief pause, return to the starting position.\n
Seated Scissor Kick                                   | Isolation | Abdominals  | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Scissor Kick                                  | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | To begin, lie down with your back pressed against the floor or on an exercise mat (optional). Your arms should be fully extended to the sides with your palms facing down. Note: The arms should be stationary the entire time.\n With a slight bend at the knees, lift your legs up so that your heels are about 6 inches off the ground. Contract your abs and bring your back slightly off the floor This is the starting position.\n Kick both legs outwards, as if you were opening a pair of scissors. Bring your legs back to the center and cross them over each other (closing scissors).\n Perform the scissor kick in alternating fashion, keeping your abs flexed at all times.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
Sled Reverse Flye                                     | Compound  | Shoulders   | Other         | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to a light weight.\n Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line. Take both handles at arms length at about waist level. Bend the knees slightly and keep your chest and head up. This will be your starting position.\n Without flexing the elbow, pull the handles upward and apart, performing a reverse fly with some external rotation. Your palms should be facing forward as you do this.\n Return to the starting position, taking a couple steps back to take the slack out of the line.\n
Dumbbell thruster                                     | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Dumbbell      | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Push-press                                    | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a standing position with a dumbbell in each hand. Clean the dumbbells to shoulder height utilizing a jumping motion and shoulder rotation. Your palms should be facing each other and the elbows pointed forward. Look directly forward, keep your chest up, and place your feet about shoulder-width apart. This will be your starting position.\n Initiate the movement with a squat, flexing the knees and hips to lower your body. Descend as far as flexibility allows, maintaining good posture in the spine, hips, and knees.\n Pause for a brief moment at the bottom of the squat before returning to a standing position by extending the hips and knees.\n After fully rising to a standing position, press the weights overhead by extending the elbows and flexing at the shoulder.\n Return the weights to the shoulder before repeating the entire movement for additional repetitions.\n
Thigh killa                                           | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a standing position with your feet hip-distance apart and your hands behind your head. Descend into a squat position by bending at the knees and hips. This will be your starting position.\n Take two small jumps out, then two small jumps back in, making sure that your feet never come closer than hip-distance.\n Throughout the entire movement, you’ll want to stay in the squat position, keeping your hips back, butt down, and chest up.\n Continue for the recommended time or number of reps.\n
Sumo Deadlift with Bands                              | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Barbell       | Powerlifting          | Beginner     | 0   | Sumo deadlift                                 | Sumo Deadlift with Chains                             | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | To deadlift with short bands, simply loop them over the bar before you start, and step into them to set up. Ensure that they under the back half of your foot, directly where you are driving into the floor.\n Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip.\n Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.\n As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.\n Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.\n
Partner Facing Feet-Elevated Side Plank With Band Row | Compound  | Middle Back | Bands         | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Get into a side plank position by balancing your weight on one elbow and stacking your feet about 6 inches off the floor. Keeping your body straight, lift your hips off the floor. Your body should face your partner, about 7 feet away.\n Grasp one end of an elastic band with your top-side hand, arm extended. This will be your starting position.\n Without twisting your bodies, simultaneously pull your elbows back as far as possible in a rowing motion to stretch the band, then release and again extending your arms forward.\n Do all reps for one side before switching sides.\n
Barbell reverse lunge                                 | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Barbell       | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | Barbell Bulgarian split squat                 | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Position a weighted bar across your upper back holding the ends with your hands to keep it stable. Alternately, you can do this in a squat rack to more easily get into the starting position. Stand erect with your chest out and your shoulders back, maintaining the natural curve in your back and knees unlocked. Your feet should be about hip width apart. This is your starting position.\n Staying erect, initiate the movement by stepping back with one foot about 2 feet, keeping your hips facing forward as the toe of your back foot makes contact first. Then allow both knees to bend and descend just short of allowing your trailing knee to touch the floor.\n Your body should continue to be upright. Don't lean forward or allow you back to round. Press back up by pushing through your back foot maintaining balance as you return to the starting position.\n Repeat on the opposite side, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.\n
One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press                        | Isolation | Chest       | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on the floor holding a kettlebell with one hand, with your upper arm supported by the floor. The palm should be facing in.\n Press the kettlebell straight up toward the ceiling, rotating your wrist.\n Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.\n
Prone Manual Hamstring                                | Isolation | Hamstrings  | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | You will need a partner for this exercise. Lay face down with your legs straight. Your assistant will place their hand on your heel.\n To begin, flex the knee to curl your leg up. Your partner should provide resistance, starting light and increasing the pressure as the movement is completed. Communicate with your partner to monitor appropriate resistance levels.\n Pause at the top, returning the leg to the starting position as your partner provides resistance going the other direction.\n
Suspended Leg Curl                                    | Compound  | Hamstrings  | Other         | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | Seated Leg Curl                               | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie on your back in front of suspension straps adjusted to 12 to 18 inches off the ground. Place your feet in the straps, and then push down to raise your hips from the floor. Extend the knees, remembering to keep the body straight. This will be your starting position.\n To perform the movement, flex the knees, drawing your feet towards your glutes. Pause at the peak of the contraction, and then slowly return to the starting position.\n
Single-Leg Box Jump                                   | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Other         | Plyometrics           | Beginner     | 0   | Box jump                                      | Step-up with knee raise                               | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Select a box or step of a height appropriate to your abilities. Single-leg jumps will require lower boxes than double-legged versions, and caution should be used due to a higher risk associated with the exercise. To begin, stand 6-12 inches in front of the box. Your feet should be shoulder-width apart, your knees and hips slightly bent, with good posture throughout your spine. This will be your starting position.\n To initiate the movement, lift one foot slightly off the floor to transfer the load to the working leg. Begin flexing the hips and knees into a quarter squat, generating an elastic force that will be used to power your jump. Swing your arms behind you in preparation for the movement.\n Explode out of the hole, extending your hip, knee, and ankle of your working leg to propel you upward and slightly forward, striving for maximum height. Swing your arms forward as you jump for added momentum.\n As you land on the platform, absorb the impact by allowing the hips and knees to flex into a partial squat. Use both legs to step down and return to the starting position. It is not advised to jump down from the box during this exercise.\n
Hollow-hold ball toss                                 | Isolation | Abdominals  | Medicine Ball | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lie supine on the floor holding a medicine ball between your hands just off your chest with your head and feet just off the floor, legs fully extended. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping your abdominals isometrically contracted to prevent your feet from touching the floor, throw the ball a few feet directly upward and catch it on the way down. Immediately repeat again for reps or time.\n
Southpaw sprawl                                       | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a standing position with your chest up and your feet hip-width apart. This will be your starting position.\n Bend at the knees and hips, placing one hand on the ground and jumping your feet out slightly wider than hip-distance apart.\n Keeping your one hand on the ground, quickly cross your feet, then jump them back out before jumping into a wide squat.\n Jump back up to the starting position and repeat with the other arm. Make sure to alternate arms each rep.\n
Conan's Wheel                                         | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Other         | Strongman             | Beginner     | 0   | Zercher squat                                 | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | With the weight loaded, take a zurcher hold on the end of the implement. Place the bar in the crook of the elbow and hold onto your wrist. Try to keep the weight off of the forearms.\n Begin by lifting the weight from the ground. Keep a tight, upright posture as you being to walk, taking short, fast steps. Look up and away as you turn in a circle. Do not hold your breath during the event. Continue walking until you complete one or more complete turns.\n
JM Press With Bands                                   | Isolation | Triceps     | Barbell       | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Load the bar to an appropriate weight for your training. Attach short bands to the bar, anchoring them to heavy dumbbells that cannot move.\n Lay on the bench with your feet flat on the ground, driving through with your hips. Your back should be arched and your shoulder blades retracted.\n Take a medium pronated grip, covering the rings on the bar. Remove the bar from the rack, holding the weight above your clavicle with your arms extended. This will be your starting position.\n Lower the bar by displacing your elbows forward. The bar should only move vertically, making the exercise resemble a hybrid bench press and skull-crusher.\n Lower the weight but stop short of allowing it to touch your chest, then return the bar to the starting position.\n
Kettlebell side squat                                 | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a standing position with your chest up and your feet hip-width apart. Bend your knees to pick up the kettlebell and swing it up to chest level. This will be your starting position.\n Step one foot out to the side, bringing your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width. Bend at the knees and hips, pushing your hips back. Continue until your thighs are parallel to the ground.\n Return to the starting position by extending at the hips and knees and repeat on the opposite side.\n Complete for the recommended number of repetitions.\n
Single-Leg Hop Progression                            | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Other         | Plyometrics           | Beginner     | 0   | Alternate Leg Diagonal Bound                  | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Arrange a line of cones in front of you. Assume a relaxed standing position, balanced on one leg. Raise the knee of your opposite leg. This will be your starting position.\n Hop forward, jumping and landing with the same leg over the cone.\n Use a countermovement jump to hop from cone to cone.\n At the end, turn around and go back on the other leg.\n
Partner resistance standing twist                     | Compound  | Abdominals  | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand erect with your knees unlocked 3 to 4 feet in front of and facing your partner. Place your hands together and extend your arms out in front of you. This will be your starting position.\n Your partner should push your arms out to one side as you resist; then release back toward your midline and repeat for all reps to one side before switching sides.\n Make sure to engage your obliques to twist back toward the middle, not just moving at the shoulders.\n
Rickshaw Deadlift                                     | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Other         | Strongman             | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Load the frame with the desired weight. Center yourself between the handles. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hips to grip the handles, allowing your shoulder blades to protract.\n With your feet and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and flex the knees. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. As the weight comes up, pull your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward.\n Lower the weight by bending at the hips and guiding it to the ground.\n
Burpee to pull-up                                     | Isolation | Lats        | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin standing under a bar with your legs shoulder-width apart. This will be your starting position.\n Descend into a squat by pushing your hips and butt backwards. Continue down until the upper legs are at or just below parallel to the floor. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.\n Place your hands on the floor and kick your legs back so you end up with your stomach and thighs on the floor. Your elbows should be bent. This should be done quickly.\n From this position, press up like you're doing a push-up and push your hips up. Jump your feet under your hips and begin to stand as you prepare to jump up.\n Finish the movement by jumping in the air and bringing your hands over your head to grab a strong hold on the bar. Immediately pull yourself up until your chin is just above the bar. This is one repetition.\n Descend from the pull-up by allowing your arms to extend and then let go of the bar to return to the ground. Repeat for recommended number of repetitions.\n
Return Push from Stance                               | Compound  | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | You will need a partner for this drill.\n Begin in an athletic 2 or 3 point stance.\n At the signal, move into a position to receive the pass from your partner.\n Catch the medicine ball with both hands and immediately throw it back to your partner.\n You can modify this drill by running different routes.\n
Barbell pull-over to press                            | Isolation | Lats        | Barbell       | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Lay on a flat bench with your feet flat on the floor. Hold a barbell on your chest with a shoulder-width, pronated grip. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping the elbows bent to about 90 degrees, rotate the barbell over and behind your head.\n Return the barbell to your chest, again keeping the elbows again fixed at the same angle.\n Press the barbell straight up by extending the elbows, and then return the weight to the starting position.\n
Stride Jump Crossover                                 | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | Single Leg Push-off                           | Single-Leg Lateral Hop                                | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand to the side of a box with your inside foot on top of it, close to the edge.\n Begin by swinging the arms upward as you push through the top leg, jumping upward as high as possible. Attempt to drive the opposite knee upward.\n Land in the opposite position that you started, on the opposite side of the box. The foot that was initially on the box will now be on the ground, with the opposite foot now on the box.\n Repeat the movement, crossing back over to the other side.\n
Typewriter push-up                                    | Compound  | Chest       | Body Only     | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in the "up" position of a push-up: arms extended, back and neck in a straight line, and core tight. This will be your starting position.\n Descend into the bottom position of the push-up by flexing at the elbows into a 90-degree position.\n Lean (and shift your body weight) to one side by attempting to place your front deltoid on your palm. Simultaneously, extend your opposite arm into a straight line. Your bent arm may move slightly to accommodate your other arm fully extending. This is okay.\n Next, transition your weight to your opposite arm, repeating the same motions. Once completed, this is one repetition.\n Rock back and forth, and repeat for recommended number of repetitions.\n
Feet Jack                                             | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Unknown       | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | Jumping jack-                                 | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Start with your feet together, arms bent, and elbows at your side.\n At the same time, jump both feet out to the side, allowing your elbows to swing out slightly.\n Immediately reverse the motion by jumping back to the starting position and bringing your elbows back into your side.\n Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\n
Wall shoulder tap                                     | Isolation | Shoulders   | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin in a push-up position with your feet against the wall.\n Walk your feet up the wall while simultaneously walking your hands back towards the wall. Keep your core as tight as possible. Walk up until you are as flat to the wall as you can get.\n Shift your weight towards one side, removing the opposite hand and touching the opposite shoulder. Be sure to keep the shoulders shrugged up as you shift your weight from one hand to the other.\n Repeat for the recommended number of repetitions.\n Once all reps have been completed, walk your hands away from the wall and your feet down the wall until you are back in the push-up position.\n
Rack Delivery                                         | Compound  | Shoulders   | Barbell       | Olympic Weightlifting | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | This drill teaches the delivery of the barbell to the rack position on the shoulders. Begin holding a bar in the scarecrow position, with the upper arms parallel to the floor, and the forearms hanging down. Use a hook grip, with your fingers wrapped over your thumbs.\n Begin by rotating the elbows around the bar, delivering the bar to the shoulders. As your elbows come forward, relax your grip. The shoulders should be protracted, providing a shelf for the bar, which should lightly contact the throat.\n It is important that the bar stay close to the body at all times, as with a heavier load any distance will result in an unwanted collision. As the movement becomes smoother, speed and load can be increased before progressing further.\n
Cross Crunch                                          | Compound  | Abdominals  | Body Only     | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | Cross-Body Crunch                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin lying on your back with your knees bent.\n Raise your shoulders off the floor, but don't sit all the way up. Your abdominals should be flexed.\n From this position, reach toward your right knee with your left hand. When your left hand touches your knee, bring it down toward your hip as you reach toward your left knee with your right hand.\n Continue to alternate reaches while keeping your abdominals flexed.\n
Dumbbell suitcase carry                               | Compound  | Forearms    | Dumbbell      | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Place a dumbbell on the floor in front of you, making sure you have enough open space to walk. If you can’t reach the floor safely without rounding and twisting your back, elevate the weight off the floor. (When doing this as a competition, start side by side with your partner and make sure there’s enough room for both of you.)\n Squat down keeping your back flat—don’t bend over—and grasp the weight with a neutral grip. Keep your body square as much as possible. Stand back up by extending at the hips and knees; this will be your starting position.\n Keeping the weight at your side and maintaining a body position that doesn’t favor one side, walk forward as far as you can; if necessary turn around and return the other way. Try to beat your partner for both distance and time.\n Descend into a squat to lower the weight back to the floor.\n
Dumbbell front squat                                  | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Dumbbell      | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand with your feet slightly wider than hip-width apart, holding a pair of light dumbbells down by your sides. Clean the dumbbells up to your shoulders so that one end of each dumbbell rests on top of each shoulder. Balance the dumbbells on your shoulder by holding on to dumbbells with elbows facing forward. This will be your starting position.\n Keeping your head facing forward, your back straight, and your chest high, squat down by bending your hips back while allowing knees to come forward slightly, keeping your back straight and knees pointed in the same direction as your feet. Descend until your thighs are at parallel, or just past parallel to floor.\n To return to the starting position, extend your knees and hips until your legs are straight. Repeat for the recommended number of reps.\n
Carioca quick step                                    | Compound  | Adductors   | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | The carioca quick step simulates coming out of the lateral power motion.\n\n Begin with your feet a few inches apart and your left arm up in a relaxed, athletic position.\n With your right foot, quick step behind and pull the knee up.\n Fire your arms back up when you pull the right knee, being sure that your knee goes straight up and down. Avoid turning your feet as you move and continue to look forward as you move to the side.\n
Split Clean                                           | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Barbell       | Olympic Weightlifting | Beginner     | 0   | Power clean                                   | Clean                                                 | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.\n Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so.\n Receive the bar with the feet split, aggressively moving one foot forward and one foot back. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom position, which will help in the recovery.\n Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Bring the feet together as you stand up.\n
Single-cone sprint drill                              | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Other         | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | This drill teaches quick foot action. You need a single cone. Begin standing next to the cone with one arm back and one arm forward.\n Chop the feet as quickly as possible, blocking with the arms. Circle the cone, keep your knees up, with violent foot action.\n Rest after three trips around the cone.\n
Heavy Bag Thrust                                      | Compound  | Chest       | Other         | Plyometrics           | Beginner     | 0   | Kettlebell plyo push-up                       | Plyo push-up                                          | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Utilize a heavy bag for this exercise. Assume an upright stance next to the bag, with your feet staggered, fairly wide apart. Place your hand on the bag at about chest height. This will be your starting position.\n Begin by twisting at the waist, pushing the bag forward as hard as possible. Perform this move quickly, pushing the bag away from your body.\n Receive the bag as it swings back by reversing these steps.\n
Diamond push-up                                       | Compound  | Chest       | Body Only     | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Get in the modified push-up position on your knees but with your hands together and back flat. Spread your fingers so that your index fingers and thumbs form a diamond, and extend your arms. This is your start position.\n Allow your elbows to break, lowering your chest toward the floor while keeping your back flat.\n Press back up to full arm extension, repeating for the required number of reps.\n To make the movement more difficult, stay up on your toes rather than on your knees.\n
Single-Leg Stride Jump                                | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Other         | Plyometrics           | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand to the side of a box with your inside foot on top of it, close to the edge.\n Begin by swinging the arms upward as you push through the top leg, jumping upward as high as possible. Attempt to drive the opposite knee upward.\n Land in the same position that you started, using your inside leg to decelerate the impact.\n
Side Standing Long Jump                               | Compound  | Quadriceps  | Body Only     | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin standing with your feet hip width apart in an athletic stance. Your head and chest should be up, knees and hips slightly bent. This will be your starting position.\n Leaning to your right, extend through your hips, knees, and ankles to jump into the air. Block with the arms to lead the movement, jumping as far to your right as you can.\n Land facing the same direction with your feet hip width apart, absorbing the impact through your lower body.\n
Dumbbell lateral hop to sprint                        | Compound  | Quadriceps  | None          | Plyometrics           | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Begin this exercise by standing with your feet hip-width apart and holding light weight dumbbells down by your side. This will be your starting position.\n While holding on to the dumbbells, hop back and forth over an imaginary line four times before turning to your left and sprinting about 20 feet.\n As soon as you finish your sprint, repeat the exercise by performing 4 more lateral hops, turning to your left, and sprinting back to your original starting position.\n Complete for recommended number of reps or time.\n
Plate shoulder circle big to small                    | Compound  | Shoulders   | Other         | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Stand erect holding two 5-lb. plates directly out to your sides, arms fully extended. Position your thumbs on the outer edge of the plates and several fingers through the inside hole for a more secure grip. The plates should be horizontal to the floor. This will be your starting position.\n Using a circular but deliberate motion do multiple arm circles, first starting with a small rotation and progressing to larger ones. Reverse course so you're again doing progressively smaller circles, then switch so you’re doing it in the opposite direction. Again repeat from a smaller to larger circular motion.\n
Close-stance dumbbell front squat                     | Isolation | Quadriceps  | Barbell       | Strength              | Intermediate | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Position your legs using a very narrow stance (feet a few inches apart) with the toes slightly pointed out and knees slightly bent. Hold a dumbbell (hand on each end) at chest level, with your elbows tucked inwards to your side. Keep your neck neutral and maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.\n Descend into a squat by pushing your hips and butt backwards. Continue down until the upper legs are at or just below parallel to the floor. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.\n Once you reach your bottom position, begin to push through your heels to ascend upwards and return to the starting position.\n Repeat for recommended number of repetitions.\n
One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch                       | Isolation | Shoulders   | Kettlebells   | Strength              | Beginner     | 0   | -                                             | -                                                     | -                                                   | -                                       | -                             | -                        | -                        | -                   | -                     | Hold a kettlebell in one hand by the handle.\n Squat towards the floor, and then reverse the motion, extending the hips, knees, and finally the ankles, to raise the kettlebell overhead.\n After fully extending the body, descend into a lunge position to receive the weights overhead, one leg forward and one leg back. Ensure you drive through with your hips and lock the ketttlebells overhead in one uninterrupted motion.\n Return to a standing position, holding the weight overhead, and bring the feet together. Lower the weight to return to the starting position.\n
